Comment: I think generalizations  keep things at status quo. The important point you bring up is that restaurants have a lot of financial pressures from everywhere to juggle; and the net result is \_something\_ is going to be impacted:  The problem with modernity is not just that a sandwich can cost 20$, it's that the customer has to choose between a set of bad options, not necessarily always high price. Some vendors can choose to compromise on portion size, ingredient quality, less parking or cleanliness, or just charge more because it's a high-income / high traffic area with not many competitors.  If the base costs are high the restaurant also has no incentive to offer any "deals", for example a  bowl of rice for 2.50$. Even though rice can bring in enough margin, they need still need to upsell you to take care of all their other costs, such as charging 3$ for a fountain soda.  We end in a weird situation where if someone wants to eat at restaurants for 3 meals a day, they are gonna pay 80$-100$/day for what amounts to 20$-40$ worth of food.  While it makes "sense" for people to pay 25$ for a lunch every now and again to compensate all the middlemen and overhead, and convenience of their staff being available at the moment you decide you're hungry, it scales really badly for the end customer.  As a customer, I don't want to be paying for a fixed cost of building rent in a variable, per meal format. I like paying for convenience, but it seems in the food service industry there's no mechanism for scaling quality food at a decent price.  The other issue is of course sales tax, basic groceries are tax-free but most restaurants are taxed 10-15% in Canada. Again another "convenience cost" that scales badly.  I'm not suggesting the government steps in to solve all our problems by offering free rent to restaurants, but some point we need to stop finding excuses to justify a 7$ item costing 25$ even for repeat customers.
